newsitem.title: USA: N.J. proposes $1.8 bln in transportation spending.
newsitem.headline: N.J. proposes $1.8 bln in transportation spending.

text.p: New Jersey's Transportation Commissioner on Tuesday proposed a $1.8 billion transportation capital spending program for fiscal 1998, one of the largest capital budgets in state history.

Commissioner John J. Haley, Jr., said he officially transmitted the spending proposal on Tuesday to the state Legislature for inclusion in Gov. Christine Whitman's budget for fiscal 1998, which begins July 1.
"In line with the Governor's emphasis on supporting local governments, this program provides $270 million to counties and municipalities," Haley said in a statement announcing the plan.

Haley said he had also asked for increased appropriations of $200 million from the state's Transportation Trust Fund, which normally contributes about $700 million annually to state capital spending projects.
"This increase is made possible by lower-than-anticipated financing costs in the Trust Fund and will not affect the overall financial outlook of the current Trust Fund authorization act," Haley said.

Haley said the Department's spending plans direct particular attention to New Jersey's bridges. There are more than 15 bridges that will require replacement or major rehabilitation in the next seven years at a total cost of more than $1.4 billion, he said.
